Some methods are just plain ridiculous and maybe even pointless if you stick too much to the rules. Yeah, I’m talking about rules again. So, if I think someone might be a criminal in a case I’m handling… you’re studying law, right, Rodion Romanovitch? 

‘Yeah, I was…’

‘Well, this is a good lesson for you—though I won’t pretend to teach you anything after those articles you’ve written about crime! I’m just saying, if I suspect someone of being guilty, why should I stress them out too early, even if I have some evidence? Sometimes I have to arrest someone right away, but other times, the situation is different. So why not let them roam around for a bit? He-he-he! But I see you’re not quite getting it, so let me break it down. If I lock someone up too soon, I might actually give them a boost, you know? He-he! You’re laughing?’

Raskolnikov wasn’t laughing at all. He was sitting there with tight lips, his intense eyes locked on Porfiry Petro-vitch. 

‘But that’s true for certain types of people. Everyone’s different. You mention “evidence.” Sure, there can be evidence. But evidence can be interpreted in different ways. I’m an examining lawyer, and I’ll admit I’m not the strongest. I want to make my proof super clear, like math. It should be as solid as two plus two equals four—direct and undeniable!’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The speaker discusses the complexities of handling criminal suspects and the nuances of evidence in legal proceedings.
